text: today on x cast israel strikes gaza
after militants kill seven israelis and
wound 40 near the popular red sea resort
of a lot president obama and the leaders
of Germany Britain France and Canada
called for Syria's President Bashar al
Assad to step down the transition to
democracy in Syria has begun and it's
time for Assad to get out of the way and
the op-ed columnist Roger Cohen on the
regional implications if the Syrian
president resigns if you did leave it
could be important for one US strategic
game which is the isolation of Iran
today across the border in Israel near
the town of I lot a group of unknown
gunmen in a series of three attacks took
the lives of seven Israelis using rifles
and anti-tank weapon and roadside bombs
in the aftermath the attack all eyes on
both sides of the border are focused on
the North Sinai region of Egypt that
area has been an arena of growing
lawlessness since the overthrow of
president Haas Mubarak five months ago
police have largely retreated and left
the area in the control of local Bedouin
tribes smuggling under the borders into
Gaza has exploded not just materials but
also people moving back and forth
through the borders most people in
Israel and in Egypt think it stands to
reason that either Islamists from Gaza
move through Sinai and back across the
border into Israel to conduct the
attacks or these were radicals from
inside Egypt who moved into Israel to
conduct these attacks
this episode comes against a backdrop of
growing tension between Israel and Egypt
Israel has been increasingly concerned
about the direction of the Egyptian
government since the ouster of President
Hosni Mubarak President Mubarak was
their most steadfast ally in the region
and he held in check a populist which is
really quite hostile to Israel and so as
Egypt moves towards democracy that's a
movement which many in the Israeli
government view with anxiety there have
been a series of pipeline bombings
attacking a natural gas pipeline that
delivered energy to Israel and so Israel
has already felt pain as a result of the
Egyptian revolution and now many there
see this as the first actual loss of
Israeli life as a result of the
revolution taking place across the
border in Egypt on Thursday in a
coordinated effort the United States
Canada and several European countries
called for Syrian President Bashar
al-assad to resign this morning
President Obama called on Assad to step
aside and announced the strongest set of
sanctions to date targeting the Syrian
government on Thursday Secretary of
State Clinton appeared on TV to echo of
statement by the president calling on
Syrian leader Bashar al-assad to leave
power immediately the administration
announced that it was going to impose
new sanctions it called on other
countries to also follow suit the steps
that President Obama announced this
morning will further tighten the circle
of isolation around the regime his
executive order immediately freezes all
assets of the government of Syria that
are subject to American jurisdiction and
prohibits American citizens from
engaging in any transactions with the
government of Syria or investing in that
country what we've seen in the last few
days is the administration working very
hard to get other countries to go along
with this call and in fact today you
heard statements from the leaders of
France Germany the UK Canada the
European Union also joining the
president in this call and they hope
that that kind of has an amplification
effect that will reverberate a little
bit more it's not just the United States
hauling on
to step aside when in fact very powerful
countries around the world I don't think
there will be immediate impact from that
I don't think he'll leave office
immediately but i think that the
administration certainly hopes that
collective action as well as sanctions
will force his hand in some way it took
president obama a very long time too
long in my view him too cool for the
departure of Bashar Assad the Syrian
president it contrasts the president's
relatively rapid call the departure of
Ben Ali in Tunisia Gaddafi in Libya and
Mubarak in Egypt allowed a sad to go
ahead with a brutal clamp down over
several months that has seen hundreds
perhaps thousands of Syrians kills
still his hesitation was in some ways
understandable the aloe whites who have
ruled Syria for 40-plus years constitute
a minority and it's absolutely unclear
if I said were to go who might succeed
him if you did leave it could be
important for one US strategic game
which is the isolation of Iran Syria is
Iran's most important ally in the region
and its conduit for the weapons it
passes to Hezbollah in Lebanon if there
were a change in Syria that might
conceivably end another consideration
and for President Obama will be the
reaction of its longtime ally Israel
Israel lies unlike Libya Tunisia right
on Syria's border so as with other
transitions in the Arab world I think
we'll see a cautious Israeli response
worried that the leader with whom it's
dealt for decades is going on the other
hand hoping in the long term for some
better future
